author: @nomeusuario
title: Naufrágio de barcaça petrolífera deixa dois mortos e quatro desaparecidos na Venezuela | O Tempo
text: O naufrágio de uma barcaça petrolífera no Lago Maracaibo deixou dois mortos e quatro desaparecidos, informou nesta quinta-feira (26) a estatal Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA), que atribuiu o acidente às más condições climáticas. A embarcação "Chantase G" era operada por uma empresa dedicada à manutenção de poços. "Relatamos a triste morte de duas pessoas e o desaparecimento de quatro tripulantes", disse a PDVSA em comunicado em seu site. "Mantemos ativos os esforços de busca e resgate em conjunto com os órgãos de segurança pública". O naufrágio foi registrado nesta quinta-feira "em consequência das más condições climáticas que afetaram a zona no momento do acidente. Um comitê de investigação de alto nível da PDVSA foi acionado para determinar as causas e fornecer todo o apoio necessário às famílias das vítimas", diz o texto. O "Chantase G" contava com 25 tripulantes, segundo a Rádio Unión, que noticiou o resgate dos outros 19: nove na água e outros 10 ainda a bordo da barcaça. O Lago Maracaibo era o epicentro da indústria petrolífera, duramente atingida pela corrupção desenfreada e pela falta de investimento, assim como por um embargo que os Estados Unidos flexibilizaram nos últimos meses. A produção petrolífera venezuelana, que ultrapassava os 3 milhões de barris por dia há 15 anos, ronda hoje 1 milhão, depois de ter caído para mínimos históricos. (Agence France-Presse)

author: Sandra García
title: Captan a mujer golpeando con un bate a adulta mayor en Michoacán; la víctima tuvo que ser hospitalizada | El Heraldo de México
text: Una [adulta de la tercera edad](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/nacional/2024/5/21/adulta-mayor-marca-911-para-denunciar-su-nieto-por-golpearla-en-torreon-605145.html) sufrió una agresión por parte de una mujer que la golpeó con un bate dentro de un establecimiento de ropa localizado en el centro del municipio de Quiroga, estado de Michoacán. El hecho quedó registrado en las cámaras de vigilancia del lugar y ahora el momento ha sido compartido en redes sociales. De acuerdo con la carpeta de investigación, los hechos por los que la [ mujer de la tercera edad](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/nacional/2024/6/12/indigna-violento-asalto-contra-mujer-de-la-tercera-edad-en-slp-video-611915.html) resultó lesionada y tuvo que ser llevada al hospital ocurrieron desde el pasado 26 de abril de 2023. No obstante, ha causado indignación ahora que se ha difundido la grabación de lo ocurrido. Sigue leyendo: [Adulta mayor marca a 911 para denunciar a su nieto por golpearla en Torreón](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/nacional/2024/5/21/adulta-mayor-marca-911-para-denunciar-su-nieto-por-golpearla-en-torreon-605145.html) [Indigna violento asalto contra mujer de la tercera edad en SLP: VIDEO](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/nacional/2024/6/12/indigna-violento-asalto-contra-mujer-de-la-tercera-edad-en-slp-video-611915.html) ¿Cómo ocurrió la agresión de la mujer contra la adulta mayor? Hasta el momento se sabe que lo que presuntamente ocurrió fue que el 26 de abril del año pasado, una mujer identificada con el nombre de Carla “N” llegó al negocio de ropa tradicional de la [adulta mayor ](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/nacional/2024/6/12/hombre-de-la-tercera-edad-atropella-ciclista-en-torreon-insiste-que-tenia-la-luz-verde-611851.html)y entre reclamos, comenzó a agredirla con un bate dentro del establecimiento. A través del video de las cámaras de seguridad que ha sido difundido en plataformas digitales como X, ha sido posible observar cómo es que Carla “N” apareció con el instrumento de madera y con él tiró algunas prendas del sitio además de [pegarle ](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/nacional/2024/4/1/asaltan-golpean-hombre-de-la-tercera-edad-en-paseo-de-la-reforma-590557.html)a la señora de 65 años de edad. Cabe destacar que en una parte de la grabación se puede observar el momento en el que un par de oficiales arribaron al comercio a fin de iniciar las indagatorias necesarias para el esclarecimiento de los hechos. Juez de control vincula a proceso a Carla “N”, presunta agresora de la adulta mayor Tras la agresión de la que fue víctima, la [adulta mayor](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/nacional/2024/5/21/adolescente-golpea-su-abuelita-esta-es-la-situacion-de-la-violencia-de-genero-en-mujeres-de-la-tercera-edad-605134.html) presentó la denuncia correspondiente ante la Fiscalía Regional de Morelia. En este sentido, se inició una carpeta de investigación contra Carla “N” como presunta responsable de golpear a la comerciante. Así fue como un juez de control decidió vincular en proceso a la mujer por su probable responsabilidad en el delito de lesiones calificadas. Por ello, estableció una serie de medidas cautelares como sanción.

author: Adam PLOWRIGHT
title: Traffic jams and politics cloud Paris Olympics build-up - Japan Today
text:
With traffic snarled around Paris and political uncertainty hanging over France, Parisians are struggling to get in the mood for the Olympics party that will begin next month.
The spectacular one-off stadiums that will host sport from July 26 are now nearing completion at tourist hotspots around the City of Light, including at the Eiffel Tower, Place de la Concorde and the Invalides.
But one of the downsides of building temporary facilities at the heart of the city -- a deliberate choice to lower costs and carbon emissions -- is the disruption to the daily lives of residents.
Several major thoroughfares have been closed off or restricted, while new cycle and Olympics VIP lanes are further squeezing traffic to a standstill in some areas of the capital.
"No kidding, I see a physical fight in my street almost every day between drivers," Julien Rivet, a lawyer who lives in the centre near the Louvre museum, told AFP.
He like many other Parisians he has decided to leave the capital with his family for the duration of Games, which run from July 26-August 11, followed by the Paralympics from August 28-September 8.
Others who earn their livings on Paris' roads, from courier cyclists and delivery drivers to taxi operators are also struggling.
"We can't work any more... it's a catastrophe," complained 52-year-old taxi driver Abdel as he stood in traffic near the Place de la Concorde, the venue for Olympics skateboarding, BMX freestyle and breakdancing that is usually a key roundabout.
Organizers insist that Parisians will end up appreciating the Games once they start and that the pre-event grumbling is normal.
"I've been lucky enough to be involved in the Olympic Games in one way or another since 1982 and you always hear the same things," Etienne Thobois, director general of the Paris 2024 organizing committee, told AFP on Tuesday.
"It's true that our concept of having a large number of temporary sites in the heart of the city, obviously with that, there are constraints, but I feel like people are seeing what we're doing," he added.
"Ultimately, tourist and cultural activities have not been disturbed," he added. "You definitely need to plan your journeys a bit and make sure you're informed, but life is carrying on, businesses are working, hotels are functioning."
Many tourists in the city seem curious about the work going on around them, while giant Olympic rings installed midway up the Eiffel Tower have become a new attraction.
"I see everywhere that they are fixing the buildings and preparing for these big games, so it should be nice," Iranian tourist Mohsen, 48, told AFP.
Instead of the Olympics, attention in France remains focused on snap parliamentary elections called by President Emmanuel Macron on June 9.
Voters are set to go to the polls on Sunday for the first of two rounds ahead of the start of the Games.
Polls show the far-right National Rally in the lead, which could see them emerge as the biggest parliamentary group and possibly at the head of the government for the first time.
Anne Hidalgo sharpened her criticism of Macron on Wednesday, saying he had ruined the atmosphere.
"In an act of mistreatment of French people, the president is spoiling the party," Hidalgo told the Ouest France newspaper of Macron's decision to dissolve parliament on June 9.
The Olympics are "a coming-together of humanity through sport. Why undermine this beautiful moment with this election that was called in a hurry, without consulting anyone?" the Socialist mayor added.
Analysts and security sources have raised the risk of protests and even violence if the anti-immigration National Rally (RN) secures power on July 7 in what would be a seismic change for France.
Macron has called the election a moment of "clarification" and has warned about voting for the "extremes", both the RN and the new left-wing alliance that includes moderate Socialists and far-left Communists.
Polls show his centrist bloc trailing in third and facing major losses.
"My responsibility... is to do everything" so that the Games are "a moment of harmony, of celebration and not of violence," added Hidalgo, who ran against Macron in the last presidential election in 2022.

author: Guilherme Monteiro
title: Agricultores franceses (em protesto) incendiaram pneus e lançaram estrume contra edifício
text: Os agricultores estão em protesto em vários países da Europa. Em França, onde se queixam de não ser ajudados a enfrentar a transição ecológica, as manifestações começam a subir de tom. O relato é do correspondente da SIC Guilherme Monteiro. Os agricultores incendiaram pneus e fardos de palha à frente de um edifício publico que acolhe uma delegação do Governo em Agen, no sudoeste francês. Mandaram estrume contra a entrada do imóvel da administração pública. Tudo isto sem que as autoridades reagissem, já que têm ordens do Governo para não dispersar os protestos que têm o apoio de uma esmagadora maioria dos franceses. Há uma semana que cresce o número de estradas bloqueados por tratores. Os produtores agrícolas queixam-se que não são devidamente compensados por aplicarem regras estritas para proteger o meio ambiente. "Exigem-nos cada vez mais, pedem-nos cada vez mais e ganhamos cada vez menos. Já não conseguimos viver da nossa atividade. Atualmente, a Europa está a matar os agricultores franceses", afirma um dos agricultores. O ressentimento contra a União Europeia cresce e até contra o mercado único europeu. Os agricultores franceses já destruíram toneladas de frutas e legumes vindas de Espanha. Foram espalhadas e queimadas numa estrada. Depois dos produtores agrícolas terem impedido durante a noite no sudeste francês, os camiões com mercadoria estrangeira de seguirem caminho, o Governo de Macron corre contra uma radicalização do movimento e vai apresentar medidas esta sexta-feira. Na Alemanha, os agricultores também têm estado nas ruas para contestar a redução de benefícios fiscais. No leste europeu, os produtores agrícolas polacos juntaram-se recentemente ao movimento e exigem medidas para, por exemplo, fazer face aos altos preços da energia.

author: mid-day online correspondent
title: West Indies all-rounder Andre Russell set to retire from international cricket
text: West Indies burly all-rounder Andre Russell is all set to quit international cricket, after playing the opening two matches of a five-match T20I series against Australia, according to ESPNCricinfo. The 37-year-old Russell has been included in the Caribbean squad for two of the five-match series, which are scheduled to be played at Sabina Park in Jamaica. Since 2019, he has been an integral part of the West Indies T20I team. Having played 84 shortest format matches for the country, the right-hander has amassed 1078 runs with an average of 22.00 and a strike rate of 163.08. He also has three half-centuries with a top score of 71 runs. With the ball, the veteran has claimed 61 wickets with an average of 30.59 and the best bowling figures of three wickets for 19 runs. Russells retirement has come seven months before the upcoming ICC T20 World Cup, which is set to be hosted by India and Sri Lanka in February 2026. He is the West Indies second bigwig who has announced retirement in recent times. Earlier, their premier batsman Nicholas Pooran drew curtains on his international career at the age of 29. Russell has only played one Test for WI, while he has also played 56 ODIs, scoring 1,034 runs at an average of 27.21, with a strike rate of over 130, four half-centuries and a best score of 92*. In ODIs, he has 70 wickets at an average of 31.84, with best bowling figures of 4/35. The 37-year-old was part of the West Indies team which won the ICC T20 World Cups in 2012 and 2016. Russell has played a massive part in several T20 leagues, scoring 9,316 runs in 561 matches at an average of 26.39, with a strike rate of over 168. His resume includes two centuries and 33 fifties, with a best score of an unbeaten 121 runs. As a bowler, he has taken 485 wickets at an average of 25.85, with best figures of 5/15. He recently featured in the Major League Cricket (MLC) in the USA for Los Angeles Knight Riders (LAKR), scoring 126 runs in nine matches and eight innings at an average of 25.20, with a best score of an unbeaten 65 runs, his solitary half-century. He also took 10 wickets at an average of 32.90, with best figures of 3/30. His team failed to make it to the playoffs, finishing at the bottom of the table. West Indies squad for T20Is against Australia: Shai Hope (capt), Jewel Andrew, Jediah Blades, Roston Chase, Matthew Forde, Shimron Hetmyer, Jason Holder, Akeal Hosein, Alzarri Joseph, Brandon King, Evin Lewis, Gudakesh Motie, Rovman Powell, Andre Russell, Sherfane Rutherford, Romario Shepherd. (With ANI Inputs)

author: Meteorologist Patrick Wright
title: Hot weather brings a health risk | Covering California | actionnewsnow.com
text: Spring had a rather wonky start even with the late-season storm last weekend, but the swing to summer heat this weekend will show little mercy and leave no time to acclimate. The time to acclimate is key while tolerating the heat, especially late in the summer months. Eric Kurth, a lead meteorologist at the National Weather Service (NWS) in Sacramento, says the heat this time of year doesn’t have to set records for it to be a heat people need to pay attention to, especially if they are doing outdoor activities. One challenge for forecasting the impacts of heat is the time of year and the weather so far that season. For us, the transition to summer-like weather may be a bit harder given the cooler conditions so far this spring. Kurth says the heat this time of year is very different from the heat in August and September when we are all acclimated to it. One thing that the National Weather Service uses to communicate the risk of heat is a product known as heat risk. This takes into account the time of year and the climatology of a local area. For us, we are seeing a moderate heat risk coming up this weekend, the first one of the season. The moderate heat risk means people impacted by the heat are the elderly, unhoused, and those most sensitive to heat-related health problems. Kurth says those sensitive groups really need to be aware this weekend and it even looks like through much of next week we are expecting temperatures to be elevated. Other categories include red for major impacts and magenta for extreme impacts in significant and prolonged periods of heat. With the prospect of the 90s, something to be aware of is keeping out of local waterways fed by snowmelt. The NWS says the air may be warm, but the water is still running cold, which can have detrimental health effects if you stay in too long. The NWS also says now is the time to check your AC to make sure it works and to drink enough water heading into the weekend. The good news is that as temperatures rise, pollen production begins to shut down for some plants as they dry out.

author: Louise Miolin
title: Period poverty rife despite new products and changing stigma
text:
Period poverty rife despite new products and changing stigma
[Louise Miolin](/news/louise-miolin/13180588)for
[Story Stream](https://www.abc.net.au/listen/programs/storystream)
When 19-year-old Bronte Woolley gets her period, she doesn't buy pads or tampons.
"I use period undies instead of disposable period products because they're more comfy, and they're more sustainable, and they're really cost-effective," she said.
Period products are evolving, and so is the way people talk about menstruation — but period poverty is still a major issue across Australia.
The rise of reusables
Period underwear like Ms Woolley's absorbs menstrual blood and can be washed and reused for several years.
She is not alone in ditching disposables.
A [2024 report from period poverty charity Share the Dignity](/news/2024-08-01/cost-of-living-causes-period-poverty/104170146) showed 43 per cent of people who menstruated used reusable underwear.
It said 12 per cent used menstrual cups, which are inserted into the vagina to catch blood then emptied, washed, and reused.
Ms Woolley has polycystic ovary syndrome and gets heavy periods.
She said reusable products saved her money on monthly supplies.
"I was going through a pack of pads or a pack of tampons a day, so that can be up to $30 a week when you have your period, whereas a pair of undies is $30 and you have them until they wear out," she said.
The environment was a consideration too.
"Most of my friends use period undies instead of disposable items just because they're more environmentally friendly," Ms Woolley said.
Menstrual cups and underwear were largely unknown a decade ago but have become available in most major supermarkets.
Rapid advances in technology
When 75-year-old Margie Booker got her period in the early 1960s, belts were the norm to secure pads before adhesives became available.
Loading..."People my age would remember [the pad] being termed the surfboard because it was huge, it was cumbersome," she said.
Ms Booker said her mother's generation used rags or pieces of cloth.
"They had to dry them on the line … that would have been hard," she said.
She said when she was a teenager, a period was to be kept "discreet" and only shared with close girlfriends.
But as the products changed, so too did the way periods were shown in the media and spoken about in society.
In 1985, as tampons gained popularity, actress Courteney Cox became known as the first person to say the word "period" on American TV.
Loading...Swinburne University senior design lecturer Jane Connery, who has studied period product advertising over the past century, said periods were previously marketed as a "medical problem" to be solved.
Dr Connery said brands were wary of being explicit about menstruation.
"A lot of us remember when the liquids used to show the absorbency of the products used to be blue ink," she said.
Dr Connery said the stigma was slowly changing with more accurate depictions of periods in media.
"I get very excited to see the positive change," she said.
Loading...Products and period poverty
Despite progress in period technology and public discourse, period poverty is still rife in Australia.
The [Share the Dignity report](/news/2024-08-01/cost-of-living-causes-period-poverty/104170146) that showed a boom in reusable products also found 64 per cent of people who menstruate had struggled to afford any kind of period product at some point in their lives.
Tasmania, where Ms Woolley lives, had the worst rate of period poverty in the country with about 10 per cent of people who menstruate unable to afford period products in the past 12 months.
Across the country, 74 per cent of people in rural areas have had difficulty buying period products.
Share the Dignity founder and managing director, Rochelle Courtenay, said most programs addressing period poverty focused on pads and tampons.
But she said reusable products had a role to play too.
"It's really important to give people choices in dealing with a period in whatever way they want," she said.
Ms Courtenay said the higher initial cost of underwear and cups could be a barrier for some people as well as a lack of knowledge about what products were out there.
"People still don't want to talk about menstruation … people are just starting to learn about these things," she said.
She said Share the Dignity was preparing to launch a campaign to supply young women and girls with cups and period underwear.
"Those girls will always have access to menstrual products because they've got period undies or a menstrual cup," Ms Courtenay said.
University of Western Australia global health researcher Dani Barrington agreed that reusable products could help boost access, especially for young women.
"I think the younger generation coming through are much more open to using these reusable products from the beginning," Dr Barrington said.
"If we are going to be providing products in schools, then we should be asking 'Do you want reusable products?'"
Dr Barrington said the supply of products must be supported with a range of other measures.
"Free access to products as well as the facilities to be able to change them, to wash them, dispose of them is really key … and that needs to be coupled with education for everybody about menstruation," she said.
"Boys and girls, men and women, people who don't identify as one of those genders … so everybody understands what the reality is like."
Ms Woolley agreed with that sentiment.
"It's not something to be afraid of. It's something you should be able to talk about, and you should have access to everything that makes you comfortable," she said.

title: Astronics Announces the Innovative SkyShow Server: A New Standard in In-Cabin Moving Map Technology
text:
Delivering seamless integration, 4K resolution, and an immersive passenger experience
Astronics Corporation (Nasdaq: ATRO), a leading provider of advanced technologies for the global aerospace, defense, and other mission-critical industries, today launched the SkyShow Server, an advanced moving map system developed by Astronics CSC in collaboration with FlightPath3D. Designed for seamless integration into both new and existing aircraft cabins, SkyShow Server delivers stunning 4K-resolution visuals, enhancing the in-flight experience.
This press release features multimedia. View the full release here: https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20250402044095/en/
Astronics SkyShow Server
Developed with FlightPath3D's premier software, the SkyShow Server is an ideal solution for airlines seeking to modernize outdated moving map systems. It provides a high-performance, interactive experience, allowing passengers to explore real-time flight data and immersive visuals directly from their personal devices. This next-generation technology transforms in-flight entertainment, creating a more dynamic and engaging journey.
“SkyShow Server represents a major leap forward in in-cabin moving map technology, offering customers a seamless upgrade path and passengers an unparalleled, immersive flight experience,” said Mike Kuehn, President of Astronics CSC. “We are proud to work with FlightPath3D to deliver a product that meets the high expectations of modern travelers.”
“Our strong partnership with Astronics has led to the creation of a best-in-class solution for the moving map marketplace,” said Boris Veksler, Chief Executive Officer of FlightPath3D. “The new SkyShow Server from Astronics, running our FlightPath3D software, exemplifies the innovation and excellence that both companies strive to achieve. We’re excited about the future and look forward to a long and prosperous relationship.”
The system is highly configurable to meet cohesive branding and experience objectives, allowing personalization of colors, icons, and layouts, with over 50,000 Points of Interest (POI) pins for destination exploration. It features touch controls, augmented reality views, and real-time flight data, offering modes like tracking the plane’s journey, 360° aircraft views, cockpit perspectives, and a "flying-over-places" feature for an immersive passenger experience.
Integration of the SkyShow Server is seamless, featuring a comprehensive set of essential interfaces, including 3G HD SDI and 4K HDMI outputs, RS232 controller interface, RS232 and ARINC 429 flight data ports, multiple discrete inputs/outputs, digital/analog audio outputs, and an Ethernet aircraft interface.

author: Jacob Krol
title: Amazon CEO has exciting news for Prime members
text: Amazon CEO has exciting news for Prime members Fast Facts - Amazon's long-promised (and even demonstrated) package delivery via drone, and now it's doubling down on it. - The news comes from CEO Andy Jassy's latest annual shareholder letter. Amazon.com ( AMZN ) is home to all sorts of products, and if you’re a Prime member or willing to pay for it per order, you can get those items delivered in record time. As part of the membership subscription, Prime users get access to fast, generally two-day shipping on most items, with one-day shipping available on certain things. Amazon CEO Andy Jassy is pretty bullish on futuristic delivery methods, even ones that have been mocked in pop culture, like delivering through drones. In Jassy’s latest annual shareholder letter, the CEO writes that while Amazon’s drone delivery service — Prime Air — has been questioned by some, it’s “making substantial progress and we think of it as a very valuable future primitive capability.” Related: Report: Apple's Macs are about to get a major upgrade “Drones will eventually allow us to deliver packages to customers in less than an hour,” he continues, noting that it won’t start off everywhere or for every package. Still, Amazon believes it will be a selling point in due time. He also writes that it could be a game-changer for perishable items, potentially from Amazon Fresh or even for Amazon Pharmacy , which delivers prescription medication and over-the-counter solutions. The idea, though, is that in the beginning, a Prime Air drone could be dispatched from the delivery facility, travel, land safely, drop off the package, and return to base. He notes that it’s also a faster way of performing same-day delivery and getting the products to customers than the current solution. Currently, Amazon delivers using several vehicles, including all-electric custom Rivian vans, but also uses e-bikes and other methods depending on the service and how quickly it needs to arrive. It’s a recommitment from Amazon’s top brass, though in what could become the future of delivery, it’s still a bit far out. The comments were part of a lengthy letter to shareholders in which Jassy also discussed the prospect of AI and other initiatives within Amazon.
